user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_remove_:
```c
static int lfs_remove_(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path) {
    // deorphan if we haven't yet, needed at most once after poweron
    int err = lfs_fs_forceconsistency(lfs);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    lfs_mdir_t cwd;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd, &path, NULL);
    if (tag < 0 || lfs_tag_id(tag) == 0x3ff) {
        return (tag < 0) ? (int)tag : LFS_ERR_INVAL;
    }

    struct lfs_mlist dir;
    dir.next = lfs->mlist;
    if (lfs_tag_type3(tag) == LFS_TYPE_DIR) {
        // must be empty before removal
        lfs_block_t pair[2];
        lfs_stag_t res = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &cwd, LFS_MKTAG(0x700, 0x3ff, 0),
                LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_STRUCT, lfs_tag_id(tag), 8), pair);
        if (res < 0) {
            return (int)res;
        }
        lfs_pair_fromle32(pair);

        err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir.m, pair);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        if (dir.m.count > 0 || dir.m.split) {
            return LFS_ERR_NOTEMPTY;
        }

        // mark fs as orphaned
        err = lfs_fs_preporphans(lfs, +1);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        // I know it's crazy but yes, dir can be changed by our parent's
        // commit (if predecessor is child)
        dir.type = 0;
        dir.id = 0;
        lfs->mlist = &dir;
    }

    // delete the entry
    err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &cwd, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_DELETE, lfs_tag_id(tag), 0), NULL}));
    if (err) {
        lfs->mlist = dir.next;
        return err;
    }

    lfs->mlist = dir.next;
    if (lfs_gstate_hasorphans(&lfs->gstate)) {
        LFS_ASSERT(lfs_tag_type3(tag) == LFS_TYPE_DIR);

        // fix orphan
        err = lfs_fs_preporphans(lfs, -1);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        err = lfs_fs_pred(lfs, dir.m.pair, &cwd);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        err = lfs_dir_drop(lfs, &cwd, &dir.m);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I did not flag other pointer usages because they clearly require non-const pointers or are already const-qualified: - The function parameter 'const char *path' is already const-qualified. - The 'lfs_t *lfs' parameter and members of 'lfs' are written to (lfs->mlist, gstate updates, etc.), so they must be non-const. - The local array 'pair' is modified by lfs_pair_fromle32(pair), so any pointer to it must allow modification. - Calls such as lfs_dir_fetch(..., &dir.m, pair) and lfs_dir_drop(..., &cwd, &dir.m) use output parameters (structures filled/modified by the callee), so non-const pointer types are appropriate. - Local writes to 'dir.type' and 'dir.id' indicate those objects are mutable and should not be const-qualified. Therefore those fragments are not suspected for Rule 8.13 issues and were omitted from the suspicious list above.
